awd_titl_txt: Preparing STEM Teachers for English Language Learners: the STELLER Project
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will implement a Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Phase II project, STEM Teachers for English Language Learners: Excellence and Retention (STELLER), at the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB).  STELLER addresses the growing national need to recruit, prepare, and provide effective induction support for new STEM middle and high school teachers with degrees in STEM fields and strong content-specific pedagogical preparation.  A unique aspect of this project is the intent to focus on preparing new teachers who can meet the needs of English Language Learners (ELLs), students whose difficulties in speaking, reading, writing, or understanding English may hinder their learning.  This program seeks to recruit undergraduate STEM students across all disciplines for entry into a 13-month post baccalaureate program leading to certification and a career teaching in high needs secondary schools.  A total of 40 scholars will be supported over the five years of the project.  The new teacher scholars will obtain teaching positions in high-need secondary schools with a particular emphasis on placement in the Santa Barbara Unified School district but also elsewhere on the California Central Coast in Santa Barbara, Ventura, San Luis Obispo, and Kern counties.

STELLER's team will consist of UCSB faculty from science, mathematics, engineering, computer science, and education; teachers and administrators from the high-need Santa Barbara Unified School District (SBUSD); directors from UCSB's Office of Education Partnerships; and community leaders from the Santa Barbara County K-20 STEM Council.  The program will continue efforts begun under the Noyce Phase I CalTeach at Santa Barbara (CTSB) to increase the quality, number, and diversity of secondary science and mathematics teachers who graduate from UCSB's post-baccalaureate Teacher Education Program (TEP).  Starting at the undergraduate level, a focus on English Language Learners (ELLs) will be added so as to thoroughly prepare secondary science and mathematics teacher candidates to teach the disciplinary-specific language, core ideas, and practices outlined in the Next Generation Science Standards and the Common Core State Standards in Mathematics.  The trajectories of CTSB and STELLER Teacher Scholars will be tracked to generate new insights into effective teacher education.  This project will produce a 24% increase in UCSB's production of science and mathematics teachers. Evaluation efforts will include an assessment of activities specific to this project as well as continued assessment of the success of beginning teachers from the initial Phase I Noyce Program at UCSB.  A mixed methods approach will be used in project evaluation.  Data regarding the program operation will be collected through surveys and interviews with all participants.  Data regarding teacher effectiveness and training will be collected in classroom observations, tracking of average state standardized test scores of students, and performance on the state-mandated teaching performance assessment.

por.por_cntn:
Begun in 2014, UC Santa Barbara's STEM Teachers for English Language Learners: Excellence and Retention (STELLER) project successfully recruited, prepared, and retained preservice teachers pursuing a single-subject credential in physics, chemistry, biology, or mathematics. These preservice secondary science and mathematics teachers were provided in-depth preparation on how to effectively teach rigorous and equitable science and mathematics language, ideas, and practices to multilingual learners in their university courses and in their field placements with exceptional mentor teachers. Research shows that being taught by well-started beginning teachers improves outcomes for students, especially for those students who are multilingual learners, who are underrepresented in STEM, and who attend high-need schools.

Because of faculty mentors from key STEM disciplines, a well-established CalTeach undergraduate teacher recruitment program on campus, and a highly regarded teacher education program, across 8 years, STELLER recruited 41 secondary preservice teachers: 19 in physics, chemistry, or biology and 22 in mathematics. Approximately 60% of these scholars were from diverse backgrounds themselves, defined here as a member of an ethnic minority, a first-generation college student, or a transfer student from a community college. STELLER scholars completed three science or mathematics methods courses over the course of their program. One of these courses was organized around five effective principles of multilingual learner instruction: (1) building on and using students' funds of knowledge, (2) identifying disciplinary language demands and supports, (3) providing students with cognitively demanding work, (4) engaging students in opportunities for rich language and literacy practice, and (5) establishing a safe classroom community. Instructional language routines, defined as structured routines designed to scaffold multilingual learners' efforts to engage in disciplinary language and participate in sensemaking, were added to this course to provide scholars with concrete ways to develop high quality science or mathematics lessons for multilingual learners. Examples of instructional language routines included in the course were Three Reads, Stronger & Clearer, and Co-Craft Questions and Problems. A fourth methods course, taken by a subset of the STELLER scholars, prepared them to earn an Industrial & Technology Education credential, part of California's Career Technical Education program. STELLER scholars completed their student teaching in junior high and high school classrooms in a local district which is considered high-need (53% of the students are socioeconomically disadvantaged); over 14% of students in this school district are multilingual learners.

Research on STELLER scholars' ideas about and enactment of instruction showed that they were well prepared to teach science and mathematics to multilingual learners. As one example, in a study of seven STELLER scholars in science, we found that they developed a sophisticated understanding of the principle of disciplinary language demands and supports and how to teach it over the course of their teacher education program. More specifically, preservice teachers learned to understand disciplinary language as more than just vocabulary and were able to implement appropriate instructional supports to scaffold multilingual learners at all three levels of language (i.e., lexical, syntactic, and discursive levels). Their understanding of disciplinary language and instructional support resonated both with their experienced cooperating teachers' understanding and with their actual classroom practice.

Thirty-nine of our 41 STELLER scholars graduated from the program with a secondary credential in science or mathematics. All of these 39 STELLER scholars secured teaching positions in high-need schools within one year of graduation from the program. Sixteen of the STELLER scholars remained in the high-need district where they completed their student teaching, at least initially. At the close of the STELLER program, 35 of these 39 teachers (90%) were still teaching and were still teaching in high-need school districts. Seventy-nine percent of these STELLER scholars were also taking leadership roles in their schools and districts. These leadership activities included serving as student club advisors, developing and piloting new courses, serving on district leadership team for content, and mentoring newer teachers.


Last Modified: 11/22/2022
Modified by: Julie A Bianchini
